title: Priestly Holiness
shortSummary: Leviticus 21 outlines the specific holiness standards required of the priests, the sons of Aaron, emphasizing their separation from defilement and their consecration to God’s service. The chapter details restrictions on their conduct, marriage, and physical condition to maintain the sanctity of their priestly duties. This chapter highlights the importance of purity and dedication in those who serve before the Lord.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - The Wilderness Period after the Exodus

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The leader and prophet who receives God's instructions and communicates them to the priests and people.

keyCharacters.name: Aaron
keyCharacters.description: The first high priest and father of the priestly line, whose descendants are subject to these holiness regulations.

keyCharacters.name: High Priest
keyCharacters.description: The chief priest anointed with oil, set apart for special service and held to even stricter standards of holiness.

definitions.definition: To make ceremonially unclean or impure, especially by contact with death or sin, disqualifying one from sacred service.
To treat something sacred with irreverence or disrespect, thereby desecrating it.
A physical defect or imperfection that disqualifies a priest from offering sacrifices or entering the sanctuary.
To set apart as holy, consecrating someone or something for God's special use.

outline.heading: Restrictions on Defilement by Death
outline.description: God commands that priests must not defile themselves by touching the dead except for close relatives, emphasizing their need to remain ceremonially pure due to their sacred role.

outline.heading: Priestly Appearance and Conduct
outline.description: Instructions are given regarding the priests’ physical appearance and moral conduct, forbidding practices like shaving the beard or marrying immoral women, to uphold their holiness.

outline.heading: Special Rules for the High Priest
outline.description: The high priest is held to higher standards, including restrictions on mourning practices, contact with the dead, and marriage, reflecting his unique consecration and responsibility.

outline.heading: Physical Qualifications for Priests
outline.description: God outlines physical defects that disqualify priests from offering sacrifices or entering the sanctuary, underscoring the importance of outward holiness as a reflection of inward consecration.

outline.heading: Moses Communicates God's Commands
outline.description: Moses faithfully relays all these instructions to Aaron, his sons, and the entire community of Israel, ensuring obedience to God’s holiness standards.

application: Maintain personal holiness by avoiding spiritual defilement and honoring God with your conduct and relationships.
Recognize the importance of consecration and purity in serving God, whether in formal ministry or daily life.
Respect God’s standards for those who lead in the church, supporting their call to live exemplary lives.
Apply biblical principles of holiness by guarding your heart and body from influences that profane your walk with God.

keyVerses.text: They shall be holy unto their God, and not profane the name of their God: for the offerings of the LORD made by fire, and the bread of their God, they do offer: therefore they shall be holy.
keyVerses.significance: This verse captures the core command that priests must be holy because of their sacred role in offering sacrifices to God.

keyVerses.text: And he that is the high priest among his brethren, upon whose head the anointing oil was poured, and that is consecrated to put on the garments, shall not uncover his head, nor rend his clothes;
keyVerses.significance: It highlights the unique consecration and solemn responsibility of the high priest, setting him apart from others.

keyVerses.text: Speak unto Aaron, saying, Whosoever he be of thy seed in their generations that hath any blemish, let him not approach to offer the bread of his God.
keyVerses.significance: This verse emphasizes the physical standards required for priests, illustrating the seriousness of maintaining holiness in worship.
